importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication indicates when the new collective bargaining agreement and pay increase for WNBA players were announced, marking a pivotal moment in league negotiations and player compensation discussions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from October 1 to October 31 is significant as it reflects the deadline previously set for the WNBA to finalize a new CBA, with the league and players not necessarily completing the deal by that date.

keyTakeAways: WNBA players will receive a 'big' pay increase under the new collective bargaining agreement, as stated by NBA Commissioner Adam Silver.
The current CBA gives WNBA players 9.3% of league revenue, while NBA players receive 49%, highlighting a significant disparity in revenue sharing.
The WNBA has seen substantial growth in value—13 franchises increased in value by an average of 180%, with Caitlin Clark’s Indiana Fever growing by 273% to $335 million.
The league’s revenue growth is attributed to rising TV ratings, merchandise sales, and attendance over the past year.
The WNBA's salary cap for the past season was $1,507,100, with a maximum cap of $249,244 and a minimum of $66,079.
The WNBA players’ association (WNBPA) expressed frustration, criticizing Silver for not emphasizing revenue sharing and sharing a video of his remarks on Instagram Stories.

Player protests, including warming up in 'Pay Us What You Owe Us' shirts, and statements from Minnesota Lynx star Napheesa Collier about 'worst leadership' and lack of accountability, highlight ongoing tensions over pay and leadership.

summaryOfNewsArticle: NBA Commissioner Adam Silver has announced that WNBA players will receive a 'big' pay increase under the new collective bargaining agreement, emphasizing that the players deserve higher absolute pay due to the league’s revenue growth. The WNBA has seen a 180% average increase in franchise value, with Caitlin Clark’s Indiana Fever growing by 273% to $335 million, highlighting financial expansion. However, the current CBA gives players only 9.3% of revenue, compared to 49% for NBA players, sparking protests from the WNBPA and players like Napheesa Collier, who criticized leadership. The dispute reflects broader issues of equity in professional sports pay and revenue sharing, with the league aiming to finalize a deal by October 31, though not guaranteed.
title: NBA Commissioner Adam Silver Says WNBA Players Will Get ‘Big’ Pay Increase in New CBA
